Comment: So, I think youâ€™re slightly off on the buyback issue.  Itâ€™s not so much about manipulation of stock prices itâ€™s that if the company is sitting on enough excess cash the shareholders will push it to distribute dividendsâ€¦which are then taxed.  A buyback effectively pro-rata increases the share price, but not the market cap.  Valuation is the market cap, not the price of the shares*  An analogy just in case others might not follow:  I have a pie (company in this case), and itâ€™s split into 100 pieces (shares), and each share trades for $1.00, then the pie is worth $100.  Now, letâ€™s say I, as a company, have excess cash of $10.  I can do one of three things:  1. If I have a great investment idea I can just reinvest it into the business.  That reinvestment creates growth potential - maybe, depends on a LOT of things.  2. I can issue a dividend of 0.10 to all my 100 shareholders ($0.10 * 100 share holders = $10).  Letâ€™s say all 100 share holders are long term capital gains holders in the US, so they then owe $0.02 of their $0.10 dividend as long term capital gains taxes.  (For all you tax nerds, leave me alone Iâ€™m trying to not make this any more complicated than it is.  So in the end the US Treasury gets $2 and shareholders get $8.  3. I can buy back some allotment of stock usually at a premium.  For the sake of very easy numbers letâ€™s say I have an excess of $10 and I offer $1.25 to buy back up to 8 shares and all 8 are sold.  (The mechanics of how this works doesnâ€™t actually matter for the point of this post).  Then, I retire those shares.  So now I have a company that is still worth $100, but there are only 92 slices remaining.  So each of the remaining shares are now worth $1.08.  The pie didnâ€™t change in size, we just changed the number of slices of the pie.   *Market cap = number of shares outstanding * share price ** Bonus extra = in the most basic terms the value of a company is an estimation of the present value of its future cash flows and the share price is just that present value divided by the number of shares outstanding.  Where things get very messy is whatever that estimation of future cash flows is.
